SolutionsPage.solutionsDescription: Consolidating your site network? Need to reduce fleet costs? Redesigning your sales territories? Answer your question through the lens of location.

cartovl.title: Develop an interactive custom web map
cartovl.subtitle: Develop impressive interactive maps and use them on your websites and apps.

step1.title: Develop an interactive web map
step1.text1: Our platform provides a set of libraries and APIs to develop customizable and interactive maps. CARTO VL is a JavaScript library to develop beautiful interactive web maps.
step1.text2: In this guide, you will learn how to load the library in your project, create a map with one of CARTO's basemaps, add a data layer, and style it.
step1.text3: Interested in other libraries or APIs? Visit our Developer Center.

step2.summary: Create an HTML file using the template below that loads both the CARTO VL and Mapbox GL libraries.

howto.instruction1: Create an HTML file and add the following scripts.

extras.resource1: CARTO VL is our more advanced rendering library and new features are constantly being added. You can read about the newest capabilities in our Product Updates blog.
extras.resource2: You can also install and load CARTO VL using npm.

step3.summary: Define the <div> element that will contain your map.

howto.instruction1: Define the <div> element that will contain the map in the <body> of your file. The map, layers and controls will be displayed in this element.
howto.instruction2: Paste the following CSS code in the bottom of the <head> element to define some basic styles for the map container.

step4.summary: Add a CARTO basemap with the Mapbox GL map constructor.

howto.instruction1: Add the following script below your <div> container to load CARTO's Voyager basemap centered on the world at zoom level 2.

extras.resource1: CARTO VL relies on Mapbox GL render basemaps. Choose between carto.basemaps.voyager, carto.basemaps.positron, and carto.basemaps.darkmatter basemaps.

step5.summary: Connect to a CARTO account and add a data layer to your map. In this example, we’re using an account named public and the default public API key.

howto.instruction1: Connect to a CARTO account by specifying the username and API key you want to use. In this case, we're using a test account and a test access key.
howto.instruction2: Now that CARTO VL has access, you can add any of the datasets in that account as a source layer to display on the map.

extras.resource1: Want to use your own account? Learn about API Authorization.

step6.summary: Use styling properties to overwrite default symbology.

howto.instruction1: You can overwrite the default symbology applied to features on the map by adding custom styles inside of the Viz object.

extras.resource1: Learn more about styling with expressions.

congrats.title: Congratulations!
congrats.message1: You've just created your first map with CARTO VL!
congrats.message2: Download the full code example.

extras.resource1: Learn more with the following examples from our Developer Center.

card1.title: Style features by category
card1.subtitle: Learn how to change the style of the features by a given column

card2.title: Add hover popups
card2.subtitle: Learn how to display info about a feature when user mouses over it.

card3.title: Animate the features
card3.subtitle: Learn how to animate the features of the map by different columns.

cartoframes.title: Add spatial data to your data science workflow
cartoframes.subtitle: Bring spatial data into your data science models using our Python library.

step1.title: Bring spatial analysis to your Python notebooks with CARTOframes
step1.text1: No more⁠ context switching—visualize your data straight out of your notebook
step1.text2: Access location data services, such as geocoding our routing, and create your areas of influence
step1.text3: Spend less time enriching your data by accessing Data Observatory, our location data repository
step1.text4: Share your work right away, publicly or privately

builder.title: Create a web map from your browser
builder.subtitle: Uncover insights from your location data with our online drag and drop tool.

step1.title: Build a map with our drag & drop editor
step1.text1: Builder is our drag & drop tool to design, build and publish interactive web maps with your location data. Maps can be easily shared or embedded on any website or blog.
step1.text2: In this guide, you will learn how to upload a .csv file and create your first dataset, create a simple map, and publish it.

summary.text: Download and upload a comma-separated values (CSV) file to create your first dataset.

howto.instruction2: Visit the Data page and click the “New Dataset” button
howto.instruction3: In the Connect dataset section click “Browse”, select the file, and click “Connect dataset”

extras.resource1: You can also import your data by dragging and dropping your files into your dashboard.

summary.text: Explore your new dataset and learn how to manipulate it.

howto.instruction1: Once the upload has finished and the new dataset has been created, you will be redirected to the Dataset view. Here, you can explore your data.
howto.instruction2: Double-click on any cell to edit it.
howto.instruction3: Click on any of the columns to change the order, rename it, change its data type, remove it, or even add new columns.
howto.instruction4: You can also add new rows and export your data in different formats.

extras.resource1: Use the little switch on the bottom left of the screen to explore your dataset using SQL.

summary.text: Create a map using your new dataset.

howto.instruction1: From the dataset view, click “CREATE MAP” (on the bottom right of your screen).
howto.instruction2: Your map will be created and you will be redirected to Builder, CARTO’s map editor:
howto.instruction3: Double click on the name of the map (Untitled Map) and rename it to “My first map”. This will be the name that you will see on your dashboard as well.
howto.instruction4: Change the style of the features on the map (eg: point size, point color, strike size, strike color) by clicking on the layer name and playing with the styling options.

extras.resource1: Alternatively, you can also create maps directly from your dashboard. You can select one or more datasets from the Data page to create a map with multiple layers, or you can create a map from your Maps page.

summary.text: Publish and share your map with the world.

howto.instruction2: Click on the red privacy button to make your map “Public”.
howto.instruction3: Click “Publish” to publish this version of your map.
howto.instruction4: Your map has now been published and you can use the link or embed code to share your map.

extras.resource1: Until you re-publish your map again, you can make as many changes as you need to without affecting the published version.

congrats.title: Congratulations!
congrats.message1: You've just created your first web map using Builder

extras.resource1: Learn more with the following examples from our Help Center.

card1.title: Understanding map layers in Builder
card1.subtitle: Learn how to add data layers to your maps, style them, and more.

card2.title: Customizing Pop-Ups with HTML
card2.subtitle: Learn how to setup and customise popups with HTML.

card3.title: Exploring Data with Widgets
card3.subtitle: Learn how to add interactive widgets to explore your data.

OAuthAppsPage.title: Apps
OAuthAppsPage.description: Build your app allowing users to authenticate through CARTO to share specific data with your app. You can read more in our developer documentation.

deleteModal.title: You are about to delete {name} app.
deleteModal.subtitle: The datasets created by the app won't be deleted.</br>The deleted app cannot be recovered, be sure before proceeding.

regenerateModal.title: You are about to reset the client secret of your {name} app.
regenerateModal.subtitle: The existing secret will be revoked immediately, and the new secret immediately available. This cannot be undone.

form.appNameDesc: The name of your OAuth app
form.webUrlDesc: The homepage URL of your website
form.descriptionDesc: This is displayed to users of your OAuth app.</br>e.g: Find the neighborhood of your dreams
form.callbackUrlsDesc: The full URL to redirect to after a user authorizes an installation.</br>More than one can be setup for development purposes.
form.logoUploadLink: Upload a picture from your computer
form.clientSecretWarning: Client secret must be kept secret
form.clientSecretDesc: OAuth apps can use OAuth credentials to identify users. Learn more about identifying users by reading our integration developer documentation.
